text:
(1)
Broadway and Cortland Streets, showing Old Horse Cars.
-  About 1880.
(2)
245 Broadway, West side from Park Place to Chambers Street, opposite City Hall Park.
About 1876.

Broadway, west side, north from a point midway between Cortland and Dey Streets, across the latter to Fulton Street and showing the ornate Western Union Telegraph Co. Building at the N. W. corner of Broadway and Dey Street. This structure after several vicissitudes was finally demolished and replaced with a 28-story structure in 1913.

About 1875

Gift of H.D. Jouett

(2)

The same at a later date, and showing a more extensive view up Broadway. To the right are, St. Pauls Chapel and the old Astor House. Close observation will disclose the 2-story addition to the fourth structure from the left. This adjoins the building at the S. W. corner of Dey Street.

About 1885

Gift of Urbrock Collection

Broadway, west side, north from a point midway between Cortland and Dey Streets, across the latter to Fulton Street and showing the ornate Western Union Telegraph Co. Building at the N. W. corner of Broadway and Dey Street. This structure after several vicissitudes was finally demolished and replaced with a 28-story structure in 1913.

About 1875

Gift of H.D. Jouett

(2)

The same at a later date, and showing a more extensive view up Broadway. To the right are, St. Pauls Chapel and the old Astor House. Close observation will disclose the 2-story addition to the fourth structure from the left. This adjoins the building at the S. W. corner of Dey Street.

About 1885

Gift of Urbrock Collection

8 Maiden Lane, south side, between Broadway and Liberty Place. November 19, 1902.

Wurts Brothers.

Broadway, south from and including Cortlandt Street (right foreground) as viewed from the Western Union Building at the N.W. corner of Fulton Street. Note the Singer Building at the N.W. corner of Liberty Street, which at a later date absorbed an adjacent structure and erected upon that site an addition with a tower, 41-stories high. Trinity Church appears, silhouetted against the Empire Building. Note the cable cars on the still- cobble stoned pavement.

About 1904.

Brown Brothers.

175 to 179 Broadway, adjoining and north of the N.W. corner of Cortlandt St.

Gift of R. M. Jenks

1923.

Broadway, east side, south from Maiden Lane to Pine Street, showing in the same order, the Broadway Maiden Lane Building (170-166); the Lawyers Title Insurance and Trust Co. (164-160); the Westinghouse Building (158-150); the Guaranty Trust Co. (146-134); the American Export National Bank (128); and the mammoth Equitable Building (No. 120).
about 1924.

Edwin Levick.

text:
Broadway, west side, north from Cortlandt Street. Towering building in the midground is the Woolworth.

June 4, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

View 2 is a duplicate of the above, mounted in June 1973 with non-acidic glue, because the original print is deteriorating.
